questions.text: A 34-year-old male is being treated for tuberculosis with rifampin, isoniazid, and pyrazinamide. He has been on this regimen for the past 4 weeks. Cell Type

Description

Slide

Red Blood Cells

  • Stain deeply with eosin
  • Diameter: 6.0–8.5 μm

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with severe pain in his right elbow, which has persisted for the past two days. His mother reports that the pain is sharp and debilitating, causing him to wake up at night. On examination, he is pale and tachycardic, with a heart rate of 120 bpm. The right elbow shows swelling, tenderness, and warmth. A peripheral blood smear is performed as shown. Which of the following statements is incorrect for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Genetics

Autosomal recessive disorder; mutation in β-globin chain (Glu → Val); results in HbS instead of HbA.

Types
  • Homozygote (HbSS): Sickle cell anemia
  • Heterozygote (HbAS): Sickle cell trait (asymptomatic, protects against malaria).

Pathophysiology

Decreased RBC survival;HbS polymerises to form sticky stiff Hb precipitates- causes sickling ; sickled cells cause vaso-occlusion, especially during dehydration or deoxygenation.

Factors increasing sickling- Acidosis, hypoxia, dehydration

Classic Presentation
  • Sudden severe pain (chest, back, thigh); may include fever.
  • Acute chest syndrome:
    • Chest pain, fever, wheezing, cough, tachypnea
    • Common infections (S. pneumoniae, Mycoplasma, etc.)
  • Other Vaso-occlusive crises: (triggered by infection, hypoxia, dehydration, cold)
    • Dactylitis
    • Mesenteric ischemia
    • CNS infarction (stroke)
    • Priapism
    • Avascular necrosis (AVN)
  • Renal papillary necrosis: decreased ability to concentrate urine; may present as polyuria/nocturia
  • Anemia, jaundice, pigmented cholelithiasis
  • Osteomyelitis (S. aureus, Salmonella).
  • Aplastic crisis (transient arrest of erythropoiesis due to parvovirus B19) (Option A)
  • Autosplenectomy (Howell-Jolly bodies) increases the risk of infection by encapsulated organisms (eg, S pneumoniae) (Option B)
  • CHF, delayed growth

 

Diagnosis
  • Best initial test: CBC (↑ reticulocytes, ↑ indirect bilirubin) with peripheral smear showing sickle cells
 
  • Screening: sickling test (creating artificial hypoxia with 2% Na-metabisulphite)
  • High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is the investigation of choice.
  • X-ray:
    • Crew cut on skull x-ray due to marrow
    • Due to expansion from increased erythropoiesis (also seen in thalassemias).

 

Management of Chronic Disease
  • Hydroxyurea
    • Increases fetal hemoglobin
    • Monitor WBCs.
  • Chronic transfusion therapy
    • Risk of iron overload.
  • Folic acid supplementation
    • Prevents macrocytic anemia.
    • HSCT (TOC)

Management of Crises
  • Pain management
  • O2 therapy
  • IV fluid rehydration (Option D)
  • Antibiotics if infection suspected.
  • For VOCs progressing to acute chest syndrome
    • Aggressive hydration, antibiotics, incentive spirometry, transfusions if needed.

Prophylaxis
  • Prophylactic pneumococcal vaccination and antibiotics for patients with auto splenectomy
  • Cholecystectomy for recurrent cholelithiasis.

Sickle Cell Trait (HbAS)
  • Generally benign
  • Complications include hematuria, renal concentrating defect, and increased UTI risk.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with fatigue, weight loss, numbness in his fingers, and episodes of cold-induced color changes. A bone marrow biopsy shows greater than 10% small lymphocytes and a finding as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Key features
  • B cell malignancy
  • MYD88 mutation
  • Increased levels of IgM (Vs increase igA & igG in MM)
  • MGUS is the precursor just as in multiple myeloma

Symptoms
  • Lethargy, weight loss, raynaud phenomenon, peripheral neuropathy
  • Hyperviscosity syndrome: Headache, blurry vision, retinal hemorrhages
  • No CRAB symptoms (hyperCalcemia, renal involvement, anemia, bone lytic lesions) Vs MM has CRAB symptoms (Option A)

Complications
  • Thrombosis
  • Organomegaly and dysfunction
  • Cryoglobulinemia
  • Cold agglutinin disease (AIHA)
  • Amyloidosis

Diagnosis
  • Bone marrow biopsy and aspirate (most accurate)
    • > 10% small lymphocytes
    • Intranuclear cytoplasmic pseudo-inclusions (Dutcher bodies)
    • Dutcher bodies (PAS-positive IgM deposits)
  • Serum and urine protein electrophoresis
  • Immunofixation, increased ESR, uric acid, LDH, alkaline phosphatase (nonspecific)

Treatment
  • Rituximab
  • Chemotherapy
  • Plasmapheresis (for hyperviscosity symptoms)

questions.correct_answer: C. Cells show an increase in surface area-to-volume ratio
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Small, spherical cells without central pallor.
  • Surface area-to-volume ratio: decreased due to loss of membrane surface area. (Option C)

Associated Conditions
  • Hereditary Spherocytosis (Option A)
  • Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (AIHA) (Option B), G6PD deficiency , burns , BT reactions

Key tests
  • Both conditions can present with spherocytes and positive osmotic fragility tests.
  • Only AIHA will have a positive direct Coombs’s test.

Feature

Hereditary Spherocytosis

Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (AIHA)

Definition

Autosomal dominant defect in RBC membrane proteins (ankyrin>>spectrin) leading to spherical RBCs.

Autoantibodies against RBC membrane causing extravascular hemolysis.

Clinical Presentation

Extravascular hemolytic anemia, splenomegaly, jaundice; risk of acute cholecystitis from pigmented gallstones.

Aplastic crisis: Parvovirus B19

Hemolytic crisis: EBV

Hemolytic anemia symptoms.

Diagnosis
  • Best Initial Test: CBC (normal to low MCV, ↑ MCHC, ⊖ Coombs test)
  • Blood Smear: Shows spherocytes
  • Most Accurate Test: Eosin-5 maleimide flow cytometry, acidified glycerol lysis test.
  • Direct Coombs Test: Positive in warm AIHA
  • Cold Agglutinin Test: Effective in cold AIHA.

Treatment
  • Splenectomy (stops hemolysis but spherocytes remain)
  • Chronic folic acid replacement (assists RBC production).
  • Mild AIHA: No treatment necessary
  • Warm AIHA: Steroids; splenectomy for recurrent episodes
  • Severe, non-responsive hemolysis: IVIG
  • Severe cold AIHA: Keep warm, ± rituximab.

Types

N/A
  • Warm AIHA: IgG, associated with SLE, CLL, lymphoma, some drugs.
  • Cold AIHA: IgM, associated with Mycoplasma pneumonia, EBV, Waldenström macroglobulinemia (Option D)

questions.correct_answer: D. D) All of the above
questions.explanation:
Condition Type

Description
 

Microangiopathic Hemolytic Anemias
  • Red blood cells (RBCs) are damaged as they pass through obstructed or narrowed blood vessels.
  • Causes intravascular hemolysis due to shear stress and mechanical damage.
  • Causes:
    • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)
    • Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) / Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)
    • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
    • HELLP Syndrome
    • Hypertensive Emergency

Macroangiopathic

hemolytic anemia
  • A type of hemolytic anemia caused by mechanical destruction of red blood cells (RBCs).
  • Causes:
    • Prosthetic Heart Valves:
      • Leads to turbulent blood flow and shear stress on RBCs, resulting in their destruction.
    • Aortic Stenosis:
      • Narrowing of the aortic valve leads to mechanical destruction of RBCs as they pass through the constricted area.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with lymphadenopathy, fatigue, and weight loss. A peripheral blood smear reveals atypical lymphocytes with cleaved, lobulated nuclei resembling as shown below. Based on the histological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Nuclear Structure

Cleaved and lobulated nuclei resembling a cloverleaf; seen in atypical lymphocytes (e.g., ATLL).

Cytoplasm

Basophilic, larger than normal lymphocytes (twice the size of an erythrocyte).

Peripheral Blood Smear

Shows cloverleaf cells with atypical nuclear morphology and increased size in ATLL.

Bone Marrow Analysis

Reveals atypical lymphocytes, useful for diagnosis and staging of ATLL.

Associated Condition

Description

Adult T-cell Leukemia-Lymphoma (ATLL)

Associated with HTLV-1 infection; presents with leukocytosis,Tax gene +, thrombocytosis, and elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase levels. Imaging may show multifocal lymphadenopathy.

Laboratory Findings

Description

Peripheral Blood Smears

Identification of cloverleaf cells (CD3+ T- lymphocytes).

HTLV-1 Testing

Confirmation of HTLV-1 presence via serological testing.

Flow Cytometry

Assists in characterizing the T-cell population involved in ATLL.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with fatigue, weakness, and pallor. A peripheral blood smear reveals red blood cells that are smaller than normal and exhibit a decreased color saturation, with a prominent central pallor noted in the histological examination as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Cause

Description

Iron Deficiency



 

Most common cause; iron is essential for hemoglobin synthesis, and its deficiency leads to decreased hemoglobin production, resulting in microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells.


 

Thalassemia

 


 

Genetic disorder affecting globin chain synthesis, leading to imbalanced globin production and impaired hemoglobin synthesis, resulting in smaller, paler red blood cells. (Option A ruled out)

Sideroblastic Anemia

​

  

Less common causes are characterized by defective iron utilization, leading to iron accumulation in mitochondria and ineffective incorporation into hemoglobin. (Option B ruled out)

 

Ringed sideroblast

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents with bone pain, anemia, and increased susceptibility to infections. A bone marrow biopsy reveals hypercellularity with the infiltration of plasma cells exhibiting a distinctive fiery red cytoplasm and a prominent Golgi apparatus as shown below. Immunohistochemical staining shows positivity for CD38 and CD138. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Description

Multiple Myeloma

MM usually presents in the fifth to seventh decade of life with fatigue, bone pain, anemia, and hypercalcemia

Associated with flame cells; indicates a more aggressive disease course.

Eosinophilic Dermatosis

Presence of flame figures (eosinophilic major basic protein deposits in collagen) linked to hematologic malignancies; characterized by pruritic, erythematous papules and vesicular lesions.
